Authors: Pane M.M., Siregar C., Rumeser J.A.A.
Title: The Role of Big Data for Interactive Online Learning: A Case Study in Students' Participations and Perceptions
Affiliations: Character Building Development Center, Computer Science, School of Computer Science, Bina Nusantara University, Palmerah, Jakarta Barat, Indonesia; Character Building Development Center, Mass Communication Program, Communication Department, Bina Nusantara University, Palmerah, Jakarta Barat, Indonesia; Psychology, Faculty of Humanities, Bina Nusantara University, Palmerah, Jakarta Barat, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Pane, M.M., Character Building Development Center, Computer Science, School of Computer Science, Bina Nusantara University, Palmerah, Jakarta Barat, Indonesia; Siregar, C., Character Building Development Center, Mass Communication Program, Communication Department, Bina Nusantara University, Palmerah, Jakarta Barat, Indonesia; Rumeser, J.A.A., Psychology, Faculty of Humanities, Bina Nusantara University, Palmerah, Jakarta Barat, Indonesia
Abstract: The study aimed to gain the performance of students' participations and perceptions in interactive online learning and to understand the role of big data in enhancing it. The study adapted the quantitative method. The respondents amounted 201 students of more than five departments with a different range of semesters. The study measured the participations and perceptions of the respondents when doing teamwork virtually using the online learning management system with the Likert scale on the scale of 1 to 5 with corrected item-total correlations 0.472, and α 0.613 (> 0.5). The performance of it is moderate to low for most of respondents. © 2020 ACM.
Author Keywords: Big data; learning management system; online learning; participations; perceptions
Index Keywords: Big data; Human resource management; Students; Likert scale; Online learning; Quantitative method; E-learning

Authors: Mario E.C., Sobarna C., Rumeser J.A.A., Ardiati R.L.
Title: Forms of address and organisational culture in Japan's creative industry
Source title: International Journal of Innovation, Creativity and Change
Affiliations: Faculty of Cultural Science, Universitas Padjadjaran, Bandung-West Java45363, Indonesia; Faculty of Humanities, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Mario, E.C., Faculty of Cultural Science, Universitas Padjadjaran, Bandung-West Java45363, Indonesia; Sobarna, C., Faculty of Cultural Science, Universitas Padjadjaran, Bandung-West Java45363, Indonesia; Rumeser, J.A.A., Faculty of Humanities, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Ardiati, R.L., Faculty of Cultural Science, Universitas Padjadjaran, Bandung-West Java45363, Indonesia
Abstract: The purpose of this research is to identify the forms of address used to superiors in companies, particularly the creative industry in Japan. This research is a preliminary study for research that aims to prove the relationship between the use of language and organisational culture in a company. The method used was qualitative research by an in-depth interview with participating employees who work in Japan's creative industry. The object of this research focusses on the use of term of address by staff to superiors. The results show that the 2 (two) companies which are creative industries used "family name+san" to address superiors, and used "family name+professional ranking" to address the highest superior in the company. This research found that using "family name+san" to the superiors brought the relationship between the superiors and subordinates closer. This condition causes the communication to be smoother and the atmosphere to become more relaxed. © 2020 Primrose Hall Publishing Group.
Author Keywords: Creative industry; Form of address; Open system; Organisational culture; Results oriented

Authors: Pane M.M., Siregar C., Ruman Y.S., Rumeser J.A.A.
Title: The application of the Lencioni model in online learning: A case study in higher education
Affiliations: Computer Science, School of Computer Science, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Communication Science, Faculty of Economics and Communication, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Psychology, Faculty of Humanities, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Pane, M.M., Computer Science, School of Computer Science, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Siregar, C., Communication Science, Faculty of Economics and Communication, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Ruman, Y.S., Communication Science, Faculty of Economics and Communication, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Rumeser, J.A.A., Psychology, Faculty of Humanities, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: The study aimed to understand the performance of students‟ abilities of leadership in conflict solving problems for undertaking the virtual teamwork in online learning using the Lencioni Model. The study adapted the quantitative method. The respondents amounted 131 students of four departments from online learning program with a different range of semesters. The study measured the teamwork effectiveness performance associated to the Lencioni Model of the respondents using the online learning management system with the Likert scale on the scale of 1 to 5 with corrected item-total correlations 0.49, and α 0.81 (> 0.5). The performance of teamwork effectiveness is moderate for most of respondents. It concludes that the teamwork abilities in the virtual teamwork of online learning students in Binus pinpoint on the awareness of the five dysfunctions of a team contribution using the Lencioni Model. © 2018 Association for Computing Machinery.
Author Keywords: Online learning; Teamwork effectiveness; The Lencioni Model; Virtual teamwork
Index Keywords: Education computing; Human resource management; Students; Conflict solving; Higher education; Likert scale; Online learning; Quantitative method; Teamwork effectiveness; Virtual teamwork; E-learning

Authors: Ying Y., Mursitama T.N., Rumeser J.A.A.
Title: Comparison of animal idioms in Chinese and Indonesian
Affiliations: Department of Chinese Literature, Bina Nusantara University, Indonesia; Department of International Relations, Bina Nusantara Universit, Indonesia; Department of Psychology, Bina Nusantara University, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Ying, Y., Department of Chinese Literature, Bina Nusantara University, Indonesia; Mursitama, T.N., Department of International Relations, Bina Nusantara Universit, Indonesia; Rumeser, J.A.A., Department of Psychology, Bina Nusantara University, Indonesia
Abstract: This study compares animal idioms between Chinese and Indonesian. It presents the comparison of two aspects: (1) the name of the same animal; (2) the meaning of the idioms. This study uses comparative qualitative methods to discover the similarities and differences of the idioms in Chinese and Indonesian. The conclusions are: (1) proverb uses dragon has positive meaning; (2) Animal like goat, buffalo, monkey, tiger, elephant, dragon, wolf, and horse symbolizes the good thing for Chinese society but for Indonesian society goat, buffalo, and monkey symbolizes bad things; (3) Animal like snake and tiger have positive and negative meaning for Chinese society but for Indonesian society have negative meaning. © 2017 American Scientific Publishers All rights reserved.
References: Hanifah, A.N., (2013) Linguistika Akademia, 2, p. 378; Mieder, W., (2004) Idioms: A Handbook, , Greenwood Press, London; Jamshidian, E., Razieh, M., (2012) Interdisciplinary Journal of Contemporary Research in Business, 3, p. 461; Li, M., (1999) Journal of Nanjing Teachers College, 15, p. 113; Cai, X., (2002) Journal of Shaoyang University, 1, p. 97
Correspondence Address: Ying, Y.; Department of Chinese Literature, Indonesia

Authors: Pane M.M., Rumeser J.A.A., Sriyanto H.
Title: The performance of SECI model implementation by Binus students in the environmental awareness socialization final project
Affiliations: Character Building Development Center, Universitas Bina Nusantara, Jl.Kemanggisan Ilir III No. 45, Jakarta, Indonesia; Psychology Department, Universitas Bina Nusantara, Jl.Kemanggisan Ilir III No. 45, Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Pane, M.M., Character Building Development Center, Universitas Bina Nusantara, Jl.Kemanggisan Ilir III No. 45, Jakarta, Indonesia; Rumeser, J.A.A., Psychology Department, Universitas Bina Nusantara, Jl.Kemanggisan Ilir III No. 45, Jakarta, Indonesia; Sriyanto, H., Character Building Development Center, Universitas Bina Nusantara, Jl.Kemanggisan Ilir III No. 45, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: Environmental matters is one of the big problems in Jakarta as the capital city. That is the reason why Binus University took part with a project called ‘environmental awareness socialization’ as an action to educate the society around Binus and the students as well. Before educating the society around Binus, who were done by several groups of the students, the students, called The Cleanliness Ambassador Program, must have the values of environmental awareness first. To have the values internalized, the students had to do this project using the SECI (Socialization, Externalization, Combination, Internalization) model, to transfer their knowledge about clean environment each other effectively as well as strengthen their teamwork. This study aimed to find the performance of the students while doing the project using the SECI model. Participants of this study were 100 undergraduate students who took CB-Spiritual Development subject (Binusian 2017) with this particular final project. This study taken using convenience sampling technique and used quantitative method by using the measurement of frequency for managing and interpreting the data. This study found that the performance of SECI model done for the stage S, E, C, and I, the highest is 77%, medium is 18%, and the lowest score is 6%. © 2017 American Scientific Publishers All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Environmental awareness socialization project; SECI model
References: Ahmad, M., (2014) International Journal of Information Processing and Management (IJIPM), 5, p. 28; Aronson, E., Wilson, T.D., Akert, R.M., (2013) Social Psychology, , 8th edn., Pearson, USA; Gourlay, S., The SECI Model of Knowledge Creation: Some Empirical Shortcomings (2004) 4Th European Conference on Knowledge Management, pp. 1-10. , http://myweb.tiscali.co.uk/sngourlay/PDFs/Gourlay%202004%20SECI.pdf, Conference Proceedings Published by Academic Conferences Ltd 0954457722, December 2015; Grzybowska, K., Gajdzik, B., (2013) Metalurgija, 52, p. 275; Nonaka, I., Takeuchi, H., (2005) The Knowledge Creating Company, , Oxford University Press, Oxford; Stillweell, W.D., The Polanyi Society Periodical, 30. , 2003–2004

Authors: Teoriman A., Abraham J., Rumeser J.A.A.
Title: Intercultural Sensitivity among private university students in Jakarta, Indonesia
Source title: International Journal of Interdisciplinary Cultural Studies
Affiliations: Psychology Department, Faculty of Humanities, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Faculty of Humanities, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Teoriman, A., Psychology Department, Faculty of Humanities, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Abraham, J., Psychology Department, Faculty of Humanities, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Rumeser, J.A.A., Faculty of Humanities, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: ASEAN Economic Community, which started in 2015, promotes the need for college students to prepare themselves with competencies that facilitate performance in cross-cultural work environments. This study aimed to map the development of Intercultural Sensitivity (ICS) among students of Bina Nusantara University and other private universities in Jakarta, the capital of Indonesia (n = 317), using Bennett's DMIS theoretical framework (2004). The data was analyzed by using Z-score descriptive statistics, t-tests, and one-way ANOVA. The research results showed that the majority of Bina Nusantara University's students are in the Acceptance stage, in which one is already able to value, respect, and appreciate different values, beliefs, and behaviors from other cultures. Meanwhile, the majority of other private, religious-based universities' students are in the Defense stage, in which one still has a persistent belief that Indonesia's culture ("Indonesia" as defined by their lens) is the most valid among the world's cultures. © Common Ground Publishing, Anastasia Teoriman, Juneman Abraham Johannes A. A. Rumeser, All Rights Reserved.

Authors: Ying Y., Mursitama T.N., Rumeser J.A.A.
Title: A glimpse of Chinese culture in Betawi bridal dress
Affiliations: Faculty of Humanities, BINUS University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Ying, Y., Faculty of Humanities, BINUS University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Mursitama, T.N., Faculty of Humanities, BINUS University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Rumeser, J.A.A., Faculty of Humanities, BINUS University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: Betawi wedding dress is influenced by culture or customs of other tribes, including the Chinese customs. How big is the influence of Chinese culture in the Betawi ethnic bride dress will be discussed along with the ornaments of a wedding dress and accessories worn by the bride. This research is a comparative study that compares the similarities and differences of Betawi bride dress with the Chinese bride dress in PRC. The results of this study is the similarities of the Betawi bride dress with the Chinese bride dress can be seen from the shape of the dress and skirt, dress materials and color, the motifs on the dress and the bride’s headdress. The differences are seen in the shape and color of footwear, headwear and vest and shoulder ornament. © 2016 American Scientific Publishers. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Betawi bride dress; Fashion motifs; Headdress; South tionghok bride dress
References: Rosyadi, T.S., Profil Budaya Betawi, Bandung: Departemen Kebudayaan dan Pariwisata (2006) Balai Kajian Sejarah Dan Nilai Tradisional Bandung; Alam, R.H., (2007) Kearifan Budaya Betawi Dan Kerukunan Hidup Beragama Jurnal Penelitian Agama Dan Kemasyarakatan, p. 143; Castles, L., The Ethnic Profile of Djakarta, , http://cip.cornell.edu/DPubS?service, Indonesia 3, 153 (1967), Retrieved Thursday, August 25; Rais, M., (2010) Tata Rias Pengantin Betawi Tradisional Dan Modifikasi, , Gramedia Pustaka Rais, M. Authors: Ying Y., Rumeser J.A.A., Oktriono K.
Title: The preliminary model of human resources quality improvement in language training toward ASEAN community
Affiliations: Faculty of Humanities, BINUS University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Hotel Management, BINUS University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Ying, Y., Faculty of Humanities, BINUS University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Rumeser, J.A.A., Faculty of Humanities, BINUS University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Oktriono, K., Hotel Management, BINUS University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: The study aims to propose the training approach of Chinese Language to optimize the human resource quality especially for local tour guide. The study contrives Indonesian tourism conversations teaching module in Chinese Language to emulate the competitor. Tourism is a social phenomenon amalgamating the human, society, group organization, and culture as the object of sociology. However, preliminary sociological study was conducted on tourism as a novel investigation. Tourism was initially regarded as a more economic activity, and the main objective of tourism development is to derive economic advantages, both for the community and local state inasmuch of the leading government sectors to elevate the revenue. Tourism is then positioned as a strategic role in national development consisting of expanding the business purview and job creation, increasing domestic income, fostering the development of the region, encouraging environmental sustainability, and embodying a sense of patriotism. Tourism business encompasses many aspects and the most instrumental aspect is tour guide service. The government magnetizes a large number of Chinese’s tourists recently. In supporting the government program, the tour guides are expected to accede with the demanding quality ones to cope the tourists who visit Indonesia. The government entailed for the solutions toward the tour guide. The study indicated the visibility of the training approach as one of the fundamental provision in improving human resources quality. © 2016 American Scientific Publishers All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Chinese; Industry; Tour guide; Tourism; Tourism
